>Curently I'm trying to minimize a root of the error since the error is
>always less than 1.0. I haven't settled on which root yet, but if we can
>settle on a precise fitness function then I think (hope) this might
>serve as the basis for cross implementation comparisons. Other variables
>are:

Not sure how you are defining error here, but normally in these cases 
one tries to minimise the sum of the squares of the errors on each 
data point.  This is partly tradition, partly because the squaring 
makes all errors +ve, partly because its the same as geometric mean 
or pythagoean distance -- if you treat each data point as defining a 
separate "dimension of error" -- and partly because it gives the 
biggest error the highest priority to be fixed...

         Ian
In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
